awd_titl_txt: An Interdisciplinary Faculty Community Using a Protein-focused Course Based Undergraduate Research Experience (CURE) to Improve Student Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
The Vision and Change in Undergraduate Biology Report, as well as other publications, recommend integration of core concepts and skills throughout the curriculum and a focus on student-centered learning environments using validated high impact practices, such as research experiences for all students. This project will engage students in undergraduate research and incorporate research activities into a classroom context using a Course-based Undergraduate Research Experience (CURE).  The overall goal is to create a faculty network using protein-centric CUREs to serve a community of biochemists, chemists and biologists, and also examine essential CURE aspects to improve pedagogical development. This project has the potential to transform the impact of teaching laboratories at participating institutions by the incorporation of quantitative, authentic research into the classroom and curriculum. 

This project brings together STEM disciplinary faculty from two and four year (undergrad and research intensive-land grant) institutions to fill a CUREs gap by creating self-supporting and sustainable protein-centric CUREs focused on the enzyme malate dehydrogenase. This protein-centric CUREs community will examine two critical aspects of a CURE: 1) the impact of the length of CUREs (course long CUREs (cCUREs) or shorter modular CUREs (mCUREs)), and 2) the role of research collaborations across courses or institutions to assess their importance for student learning, retention and motivation. Student and Faculty outcomes will be assessed using validated assessment tools and an outside evaluator working with both an internal advisory team and an external advisory board as well as the participants. This project will build a framework supporting a sustained, protein-centric CURE community to foster adoption amongst higher education institutions to impact a large and diverse set of students.

por.por_cntn:
The Malate Dehydrogenase (MDH) Course based Undergraduate Research Experiences (CUREs) Community  (MCC) is an inclusive and sustainable community consisting of a national network of faculty.. Member institutions include Community Colleges, Minority Serving Institutions, Primarily Undergraduate Institutions, comprehensive and research-intensive institutions. The original goals were to create a sustainable community of faculty teaching MDH based CUREs. where all aspects of research were incorporated into  regularly scheduled laboratory courses and dramatically increase the number of students, from a broad range of backgrounds, who experience the benefits of CUREs in their undergraduate education. To acheive this we had two overarching goals: 1)  to support faculty developing and teaching MCC CUREs, and 2) to Conduct Pedagogical Research on MCC CUREs to allow continued refinement of CURE Pedagogy. 

Labs that include a course-based undergraduate research experience (CURE) component increase student gains in discovery, ownership, and scientific identity. One barrier for faculty developing CURE courses is finding an appropriate system along with resources and support for the scientific and pedagogical methods necessary for offering a CURE. The Malate Dehydrogenase (MDH) CUREs Community (MCC) was created as part of an NSF-IUSE grant to fill a need for protein-based CUREs. To evaluate the role of the MCC in development and teaching of CUREs, a survey was submitted to faculty who were part of the MCC. The survey data showed that workshops, communication and collaboration between faculty participants, and the availability of teaching and physical resources were supportive components in the development of the MCC. Survey responses demonstrated that all three key features of a community of practice were present in the MCC. Faculty engaged in activities of mutual interest including learning new concepts in teaching the MCC CURE; they built relationships through shared activity by participating in the workshops and other MCC activities; and they created common resources such as reagents and protocols for working with MDH. Participation in the MCC also had professional benefits for faculty participants beyond providing a valuable learning experience for their students. The MCC provides a template for creating a CURE community in other areas of physical and life sciences. Creating a similar community of practice will aid faculty in successfully adopting a new CURE.

To support faculty developing and teaching MDH CUREs we developed  a variety of teaching resources and biological resources to be used in classrooms conducting research on MDH. Teaching resources are available through the MCC Web site (The Malate dehydrogenase CUREs Community (MCC). https://www.mdhcurescommunity.org,  Biological resources developed have been deposited with Addgene (https://www.addgene.org/depositor-collections/mcc/)  ensuring continued accessibility to other scientists.

As part of its scientific intellectual merit, the community conducted pedagogical research with the goal of improving CURE effectiveness and showed that even limited exposure to research improved student outcomes and that incorporation of collaboration scientists from other institutions during the CURE CURE experience  had positive student outcomes  The pedagogical data collected was deposited in a publically accessible data base for others to use (http://ldbase.org/projects/86b50f9b-f9e0-4205-9070-acee9d3b9b30) in addition to a number of scientific publications in peer reviewed open access journals (available through the MCC Web Site)

These CURE classes have involved thousands of students across the country.An additional part of the broader impact of the project in addition to impact on participating faculty our research has shown that Course-based undergraduate research experiences (CUREs) have beneficial impacts on students and the capacity to provide authentic research experiences that are accessible and beneficial to all students, especially those from minoritized groups (MGs). CUREs can be presented in a full semester format (cCURE) and shorter modules incorporated into laboratory courses (mCURE). In this study, protein-centric CUREs were implemented at two minority-serving Community Colleges (CCs) in introductory biology and chemistry courses. Using validated assessment tools, student self-reported gains, and institutional data, we examined student outcomes in control, mCURE, and cCURE courses. We also examined whether there was a differential impact on student outcomes by MG status. Our findings show that students from MGs have improved scientific literacy compared to their White/Asian peers in the cCUREs, whereas students from MGs in the control course had lower relative scientific literacy. Students from MGs in cCUREs perceived higher support to pursue STEM careers than White/Asian peers. Significantly, the one year retention rate of particularly MG students in mCUREs was 24% higher than among control students.

Taken together, these data suggest that CUREs are an impactful practice in introductory courses at CCs especially for students from MGs.thus contributing to increased diversity in science.  The sustainable nature of the community ensures that students will be impacted for years to come.

A further broader impact is the range of scientific results obtained by students in such courses contributing to our understanding of structure function relationships in an important metabolic enzyme that have also contributed to new drug development approaches to combat parasitic diseases such as malaria.
